choices.text: Ligature Strangulation
Mugging
Throttling
Garroting

questions.text: A 26-year-old woman is brought dead to the emergency department. On examination, there are multiple crescentic abrasions over the sides of her neck and lower jaw, along with deep bruising of neck muscles on internal dissection during autopsy. The hyoid bone is intact, but a minor haemorrhage is seen in the strap muscles. Which of the following is the most likely cause of death?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The presence of crescentic abrasions and deep neck muscle bruising without ligature marks indicates throttling, which is the most likely cause of death in this case.

Manual strangulation, or throttling, occurs when the neck is compressed using bare hands.

Cause of death includes:

  • Blocking blood flow to the brain through compression of the carotid arteries.
  • Pressure on the carotid sinus can trigger vagus nerve stimulation and lead to cardiac arrest (vagal inhibition).
  • Partial airway blockage, though this plays a smaller role.

Findings at autopsy may show:

  • Bruising on the neck from the assailant's grip.
  • Scratch marks or abrasions from the fingernails of either the attacker or the victim.
  • Fractures of the thyroid cartilage.
  • Inward fracture of the greater horn of the hyoid bone.

The following image shows contusions and nail marks over the left upper quadrant in a case of throttling.

Explanation of other options:

Ligature Strangulation (Option A): In cases of ligature strangulation, whether homicidal or self-inflicted, the ligature mark typically runs horizontally, though it may appear high beneath the chin and along the angles of the jaw.

Mugging (Option B): Mugging (arm-locks) involves compressing the neck by trapping it in the bend of the elbow or knee, usually from behind. Although the victim may display asphyxial features and signs of struggle, examination of the neck often reveals no visible injuries, since the pressure is applied by the soft tissues of the arm or leg. In some cases, death may also result from vagal inhibition.

Garroting (Option D): Garroting is a method in which a thin cord is quickly looped around the neck of an unsuspecting person from behind, and the ends are tightened forcefully using two sticks, causing strong neck constriction.

questions.text: As per the Protection of Children from Sexual Offences (POCSO) Act, who is legally considered a child under the law for protection against sexual offences?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Under the POCSO Act, a child is legally defined as any person below 18 years of age, regardless of gender, for protection against sexual offences.

  • The Act strengthens legal provisions to protect children from sexual abuse and exploitation.
  • The Act defines a child as any person below 18 years of age, both male and female. (Options A, B, and D Ruled Out )

Types of Offences and Punishments

Some special Provisions

  • An offence becomes aggravated when committed by individuals in positions of trust or authority, such as police, armed forces, teachers, or public servants.
  • Reporting abuse is mandatory. Failure to do so leads to punishment of up to 6 months.
  • Police must register an FIR in all child abuse cases. A child's statement can be recorded at their residence or safe location, ideally by a female officer (if the victim is female).
  • Medical examination of the child must be arranged within 24 hours, with the consent of the child/guardian, and preferably in their presence.
  • Evidence of the child should be recorded within 30 days, and the trial completed within one year in a Special Court.
  • The burden of proof is shifted to the accused to protect child victims.

questions.text: Which of the following statements regarding the "Zasko phenomenon" is true?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The Zasko phenomenon refers to the transient preservation of deep tendon reflexes shortly after death due to residual neuromuscular excitability.

  • When the lower third of the quadriceps femoris muscle, about 10 cm above the patella, is tapped with a reflex hammer, the patella moves upward due to contraction of the entire muscle. This response is known as the Zasko phenomenon. (Options B and D ruled out)
  • This response may persist for 1-2 hours after death and represents a propagated excitation of muscle fibres.

Explanation of other options:

It refers to postmortem clotting of blood(Option A): A postmortem clot appears dark red, soft, and jelly-like with a shiny surface. It typically separates into a pale "chicken-fat" plasma clot and a darker red-cell clot due to sedimentation after death.

choices.text: Organophosphorus compound
Acute arsenic poisoning
Aluminium phosphide
Carbamates

questions.text: A 22-year-old male is found dead in his room. On autopsy, the stomach contents emit a strong garlic-like odour, and red-velvet discolouration of the gastric mucosa is noted, along with greyish granular material resembling pesticide powder. Which of the following is the most likely poison involved?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The presence of a strong garlic-like odour, black gastric mucosal discolouration, and grey granular pesticide material is characteristic of acute arsenic poisoning.

  • Arsenic becomes toxic through its compounds, which disrupt cellular respiration by binding to mitochondrial enzymes.
  • The vascular endothelium is particularly affected, leading to oedema, haemorrhage, and tissue damage.
  • Poisoning usually arises from ingestion of arsenic oxide or arsenites, either accidentally, occupationally, or intentionally in suicides and homicides.
  • It can manifest as acute or chronic forms.
  • In chronic cases, the diagnosis is more difficult, often mistaken for gastrointestinal illness.
  • The clinical features of arsenic poisoning are summarised below
  • The skin may show widespread changes, appearing dry, scaly, and thickened. A "raindrop" type of spotty pigmentation can occur, particularly in skin folds and on the forehead and neck. This is shown in the image below.
  • Hair loss, facial swelling, and puffiness resembling myxoedema may also be seen.
  • Inside the body, the stomach can appear normal or reveal chronic gastritis with thickened mucosa and submucosa, sometimes with mucus buildup and patchy redness of the folds.
  • Hemorrhagic gastritis may also occur. The small intestine is often swollen, reddened, and congested, with thickened mucosa resembling general enteritis.
  • The intestinal contents may be watery and abundant, described as "rice-water."

Explanation of other options:

Organophosphorus compound (Option A): Toxic effects appear when cholinesterase activity falls to about 30% of normal. Death may occur within an hour of ingestion, but more often takes several hours in fatal cases. At autopsy, parathion is recognisable because it is mixed with kerosene, giving it a distinct smell, and may also contain green dyes used in commercial preparations. The stomach contents can show an oily, greenish layer.

Aluminium phosphide (Option C): Aluminium phosphide is a commonly used fumigant pesticide in India, available as greyish-green tablets under various trade names. When exposed to air or moisture, it releases phosphine gas, which causes widespread organ damage.

Symptoms include a metallic or garlicky taste, nausea, abdominal pain, vomiting, diarrhoea, and cough.

Carbamates (Option D): Carbamate insecticides act by inhibiting acetylcholinesterase through carbamylation, producing toxic effects similar to organophosphorus insecticides. Unlike organophosphorus agents, their impact is shorter in duration.

questions.text: A 16-year-old girl and a 23-year-old boy undergo medical examination following allegations of rape made by the girl's parents. The girl states the sexual act was consensual, and no injuries were found on examination. According to the law, what is the legal status of the consent in this case?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The legal status of the consent in this case is that consent is invalid as the girl is under 18 years old.

  • Statutory rape: Sexual intercourse with a girl below 18 years of age is considered rape, regardless of whether she gives consent or not. (Options B, C, and D ruled out)
